title: 108_s1611
content: The Commission on Overtime Regulations is addressed in Section 1. The Commission on Overtime Regulations, established in Section 1, consists of 11 members appointed by various entities including the Secretary of Labor, the United States Chamber of Commerce, AFL-CIO, and the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions. The Commission on Overtime Regulations consists of 11 members appointed by different entities, including the Senate committees on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions, Appropriations, and Education and the Workforce of the House of Representatives. The Commission on Overtime Regulations consists of 11 members appointed by various entities, including the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and a majority constitutes a quorum. The Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. The Commission on Overtime Regulations, comprised of 11 members appointed by different entities, is tasked with studying and making recommendations on modernizing the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to enhance clarity and compliance. This includes reviewing worker eligibility for overtime pay, assessing the clarity of proposed regulations, and identifying potential impacts on workers and employers. The Commission on Overtime Regulations is evaluating the paperwork burden for employers to ensure exempt workers are truly exempt, clarity of overtime pay protection for workers, and the impact on healthcare access for individuals, including nurses, pharmacists, police, firefighters, and paramedics. The Commission on Overtime Regulations is evaluating the impact of proposed regulations on enforcement and compliance actions of the Department of Labor, simplifying definitions for exempt workers, clarifying specialty positions in the workplace, and updating the exemption for computer workers. The Commission on Overtime Regulations is evaluating overtime requirements for computer workers, considering an income ceiling for exemption, reviewing salary levels for overtime compliance, and identifying obstacles small businesses may face in achieving compliance. The Commission on Overtime Regulations is evaluating ways to achieve compliance with overtime requirements, clarifying workplace conduct definitions, and identifying methods for employers to communicate policies effectively. The Commission on Overtime Regulations is studying ways to improve compliance with overtime regulations, clarify legal requirements, and address other relevant issues. They will submit a report with findings and recommendations by July 30, 2004. The Commission on Overtime Regulations will submit a report with findings and recommendations on various matters. The Secretary of Labor must ensure that any proposed changes to overtime regulations take effect no earlier than 60 days after the report is submitted. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather evidence, and use existing data and research. The Commission may gather information from federal agencies and use postal services. Commission members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Commission may gather information from federal agencies and use postal services. Commission members serve without compensation but receive allowed travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, at rates authorized for employees of agencies under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, while away from their homes or regular places of business in the performance of services for the Commission. The Department of Labor shall provide all financial, administrative, and staffing requirements for the Commission including office space, furnishings, and equipment. The Commission shall terminate 90 days after the date on which the Commission submits its report under subsection (c)(2).
